courseTitle: Determination of Vitamin C Concentration by Redox Titration

pageData.titleName1: Determination of Vitamin C Concentration by

pageData.text: The purpose of this protocol is to determine the concentration of vitamin C in an unknown sample by performing <button class='glossary-text'>reduction</button>-<button class='glossary-text'>oxidation</button> (redox) titrations. A redox titration is a method for determining the concentration of an unknown by exploiting a redox reaction between the analyte and titrant. First, develop a standard curve using solutions of vitamin C of known concentration, then compare data from an unknown sample to the standard curve to determine the vitamin C concentration of the unknown sample.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 15 minutes
Activity 1: Developing the Standard Curve - 50 minutes
Activity 2: Titrating the Unknown Solution - 50 minutes
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 15 minutes
Activity 1: Developing the Standard Curve - 50 minutes
Activity 2: Titrating the Unknown Solution - 50 minutes

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
pageData.subTitle: • Bottled or purified water
pageData.text: Bottled or purified water should be used because it lacks most of the impurities found in tap water. Water that has been filtered through a water purifier (e.g., Brita<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> or PUR<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>) also works well.

text: Develop a standard curve for known concentrations of Vitamin C.
Calculate the concentration of vitamin C in an unknown sample by redox titration.

pageData.text: Scurvy is a disease caused by insufficient dietary intake of vitamin.  Between the 16th and 18th centuries scurvy accounted for more deaths at sea than shipwrecks, battles, storms, and all other diseases combined.  Our bodies do not produce vitamin C on their own; therefore, sufficient quantities must be obtained from our diet.  Historically, this led to a significant problem during long voyages at sea.  On long voyages at sea the fresh food would be consumed first to avoid spoilage or rotting.  Once the fresh fruits and vegetables were no longer available, it led to a deficiency of the essential vitamin amongst the ship’s passengers.

So, what brought about such a large-scale problem at sea, for the British Navy in particular?  In 1753 James Lind conducted a scientific method inquiry and discovered that scurvy could be cured, and prevented, by consuming the juice of oranges, lemons, or limes.  As a result, at least one of these items became staples loaded on to each British ship.  Food was not the only thing to find its way onto ships.  Rats were a common onboard pest; these animals produce their own vitamin C with no dietary requirement for it.  When the diets on long voyages became too monotonous for some sailors, they would hunt the rats and consume them.  These sailors avoided scurvy even if citrus was not a part of their diet.

pageData.desc: A historical ship on the water with its sails unfurled.
pageData.altText: A historical ship on the water with its sails unfurled.

pageData.subTitle: Vitamin C
pageData.text: Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, is a required nutrient for normal human growth and development. It is needed to synthesize an important protein used to make skin, tendons, ligaments, and blood vessels. It also is necessary for wound healing and formation of scar tissue. Lastly, it is an essential nutrient for maintaining healthy cartilage, bones, and teeth. Prolonged Vitamin C deficiency results in scurvy, an ailment once common during long ocean voyages where food sources of vitamin C were not available. Scurvy is characterized by fatigue, shortness of breath, bleeding gums, and even death.

Vitamin C is one of several vitamins that are water soluble. Excess amounts of water soluble vitamins leave the human body through the urine and cannot be stored. While Vitamin C is synthesized by plants and some animals, it is not synthesized by humans. This means that humans need a continuous supply of vitamin C in the diet to maintain good health. The recommended daily allowance for Vitamin C is 60 mg for adults.

pageData.desc: Figure 1. A molecule of vitamin C
pageData.altText: Figure 1. A molecule of vitamin C

pageData.text: Vitamin C is found in a variety of fruits and vegetables. In addition to citrus fruits, cantaloupes, strawberries, and pineapple are also high in vitamin C. Some vegetables such as sweet potatoes, tomatoes, broccoli, and spinach also contain a large quantity of Vitamin C. Surprisingly, the peels of citrus fruits contain even more vitamin C than the juice. Because Vitamin C is water soluble, it is easily lost when fruits and vegetables are boiled.

pageData.question: Taking which of the following actions would increase your Vitamin C intake the most?

options.text: eating raw pineapple
eating boiled sweet potatoes
applying citrus peel to the face
drinking more water
reducing red meat consumption

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Eating raw fruits and vegetables high in Vitamin C provides more Vitamin C than eating these foods boiled.

pageData.question: What property of Vitamin C explains why 10 grams of raw pineapple contains more Vitamin C than 10 grams of boiled pineapple?

options.text: It is water soluble.
It is hydrophobic.
It is a pH buffer.
It is an enzyme.
It is non-polar.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Vitamin C is water soluble. It will leach out of the pineapple and into the surrounding water when pineapple is boiled.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Humans must consume nutrients, such as vitamin C, to grow and develop properly. These nutrients have different properties. For example, vitamin C is one of several vitamins that easily dissolve in water. These vitamins are considered water soluble. Some types of food preparation, such as boiling, will cause water soluble vitamins to leach out of the food and dissolve in the surrounding water. When the food is removed from the water, the vitamins stay behind. Eating fruits or vegetables raw delivers more vitamins to your body than eating fruits or vegetables that have been boiled.

img.alt: Several ears of corn boiling in a large pot of water.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Humans must consume nutrients, such as vitamin C, to grow and develop properly. These nutrients have different properties. For example, vitamin C is one of several vitamins that easily dissolve in water. These vitamins are considered water soluble. Some types of food preparation, such as boiling, will cause water soluble vitamins to leach out of the food and dissolve in the surrounding water. When the food is removed from the water, the vitamins stay behind. Eating fruits or vegetables raw delivers more vitamins to your body than eating fruits or vegetables that have been boiled.

img.alt: Several ears of corn boiling in a large pot of water.

pageData.text: Vitamin C is one of many in our diet. The of some molecules generates free radicals that are damaging to the cell; antioxidants block these harmful oxidation reactions. Vitamin C acts as an antioxidant by removing free radicals, and being oxidized in the process. A substance that is easily oxidized is also called a reducing agent. Vitamin C is a strong reducing agent that also is easily oxidized in the presence of air; therefore, the concentration of vitamin C can be altered by the freshness and storage of the sample.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes what happens to Vitamin C when it behaves as an antioxidant?

options.text: It is oxidized.
It is reduced.
It is neutralized.
It is radicalized.
It becomes water soluble.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Vitamin C is an antioxidant because it reduces free radicals as it itself becomes oxidized.

pageData.question:
Although not an antioxidant, the sodium metal in this redox reaction is oxidized in the formation of sodium chloride. Which of the following correctly describes the role of sodium metal and chlorine gas in the formation of sodium chloride?
2 Na(s) + Cl2(g) --> 2 NaCl(s)

options.text: Sodium is the reducing agent; chlorine is the oxidizing agent.
Sodium is the oxidizing agent; chlorine is the reducing agent.
Both sodium and chlorine are oxidizing agents.
Sodium is an antioxidant; chlorine is a free radical.
Sodium is a free radical; chlorine is an antioxidant.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In this reaction, sodium becomes oxidized as it reduces chlorine, so it is the reducing agent. Chlorine becomes reduced as it oxidizes sodium, so it is the oxidizing agent.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Within our cells, some molecules are oxidized and become free radicals. Free radicals are damaging to cells because they in turn oxidize other molecules that should not be oxidized. Vitamin C mitigates the harmful effects of free radicals by serving as the molecule that becomes oxidized. Vitamin C and other similar nutrients are therefore deemed antioxidants because of their ability to reduce oxidation by free radicals.

img.alt: The transfer of electrons between two reactants in an oxidation-reduction reaction.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Within our cells, some molecules are oxidized and become free radicals. Free radicals are damaging to cells because they in turn oxidize other molecules that should not be oxidized. Vitamin C mitigates the harmful effects of free radicals by serving as the molecule that becomes oxidized. Vitamin C and other similar nutrients are therefore deemed antioxidants because of their ability to reduce oxidation by free radicals.

img.alt: The transfer of electrons between two reactants in an oxidation-reduction reaction.

pageData.text: A titration is a technique used to determine the concentration of a particular substance in solution. A solution of known concentration, called the titrant, reacts with the solution of unknown concentration, called the analyte. A specific titrant is selected for the titration that is known to react completely, quickly, and with known stoichiometry with the analyte via a redox reaction. The <button class='glossary-text'>equivalence point</button> describes the state at which all of the analyte has reacted with all of the titrant and neither reagent exists in excess. At the equivalence point, the volume of the titrant is now known and the number of moles of the titrant can be calculated. If the titrant and analyte react in a 1:1 stoichiometry, then the concentration of the analyte can be calculated using the following equation:<span class=bodyParaLineBreak><span class=bodyParaLineBreak>Molarity (titrant) × Volume (titrant) = Molarity (analyte) × Volume (analyte)<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>The titration equation will only provide an accurate concentration of the analyte if the volumes of both are precisely measured and the starting concentration of the titrant is known.

pageData.question: 10 mL of 0.5 M titrant is used in a titration of 2 mL of analyte. Assume the titrant and analyte react in 1:1 stoichiometry. Given the following equation, calculate the concentration of the analyte.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>Molarity<sub class=bodySubscript>titrant</sub>   x   Volume<sub class=bodySubscript>titrant</sub> = Molarity<sub class=bodySubscript>analyte</sub> x Volume<sub class=bodySubscript>analyte</sub>

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Molarityanalyte = 0.5 M x 10 mL/2 mL = 2.5 M

pageData.question: 0.005 L of 0.1 M DCPIP is used to titrate 4 mL of ascorbic acid. Assume the DCPIP and ascorbic acid react in 1:1 stoichiometry. Calculate the concentration of ascorbic acid.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Molarityanalyte = 0.1 M x 5 mL/4 mL = 0.125 M

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Because the titrant and the analyte react in 1:1 stoichiometry, the given equation can be used to determine the concentration, or molarity, of the analyte. Start by plugging in the known values for the titrant and analyte given in the problem, then solve for the molarity of the analyte.

Molaritytitrant x Volumetitrant = Molarityanalyte x Volumeanalyte

0.5 M x 10 mL = Molarityanalyte x 2 mL

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Because the titrant and the analyte react in 1:1 stoichiometry, the given equation can be used to determine the concentration, or molarity, of the analyte. Start by plugging in the known values for the titrant and analyte given in the problem, then solve for the molarity of the analyte.

Molaritytitrant x Volumetitrant = Molarityanalyte x Volumeanalyte

0.5 M x 10 mL = Molarityanalyte x 2 mL

pageData.text: The equivalence point can sometimes be difficult to measure. For a pH titration, a pH meter or a pH indicator strip can be used to determine the pH equivalence point. The experimental estimate of the equivalence point is called the end point. When using an indicator, the indicator must change color at the equivalence point. The color change of the indicator will show when the end-point of the titration has been achieved.

pageData.subTitle: Oxidation-Reduction Titration
pageData.text: One type of titration is a - (redox) titration. In redox reactions, electrons are transferred from the reducing agent to the oxidizing agent. Oxidation refers to the loss of electrons; reduction is the gain of electrons. In a redox reaction the reducing agent is oxidized while the oxidizing agent is reduced.
A common indicator that is used in a redox titration is 2,6-dichlorophenolindophenol (DCPIP). When DCPIP is reduced (gains electrons), it changes color (see Figure 2).

In this activity, the DCPIP acts as both the titrant and the indicator. As the DCPIP is added slowly to the vitamin C solution (the analyte), the vitamin C is oxidized and the DCPIP is reduced. As long as vitamin C is still present in the solution, the DCPIP will be quickly reduced and the solution will remain colorless. Once all the vitamin C has been consumed, the DCPIP will not be reduced and will remain blue. This blue color will indicate that the <button class='glossary-text'>equivalence point</button> has been reached.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>During this reaction, vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is oxidized to dehydroascorbic acid as shown in the reaction (see Figure 3).

pageData.desc: Figure 2. Molecular equation with structures of DCPIP as it is oxidized.
pageData.altText: Figure 2. Molecular equation with structures of DCPIP as it is oxidized.

pageData.desc: Figure 3. Wedge and dash structure of ascorbic acid.
pageData.altText: Figure 3. Wedge and dash structure of ascorbic acid.

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>reduction</button> of DCPIP and <button class='glossary-text'>oxidation</button> of Vitamin C can be combined and represented by the following reaction:

HC<sub class='bodysubscript'>12</sub>H<sub class='bodysubscript'>6</sub>Cl<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>N + C<sub class='bodysubscript'>6</sub>H<sub class='bodysubscript'>8</sub>O<sub class='bodysubscript'>6</sub> → C<sub class='bodysubscript'>6</sub>H<sub class='bodysubscript'>6</sub>O<sub class='bodysubscript'>6</sub> + HC<sub class='bodysubscript'>12</sub>H<sub class='bodysubscript'>8</sub>Cl<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>N
DCPIP is blue in its oxidized state, but colorless in its reduced form. Under acidic conditions the oxidized state of DCPIP will appear as more of a purple hue.

In this experiment, a standard curve is prepared using solutions of ascorbic acid of known concentration to compare to an unknown sample. A standard curve is often utilized for determining the concentration of a substance in solution. The titration is performed first with a series of known dilutions of the substance to be analyzed. The data then are plotted to generate a standard curve graph, and the data from the titration with the unknown can be used to extrapolate the concentration from the standard curve graph.

pageData.question: The chemical 2,6-dichlorophenolindophenol (DCPIP) changes color from blue to colorless under which of the following conditions?

options.text: The DCPIP is reduced.
The DCPIP is oxidized.
The DCPIP is exposed to an indicator.
The DCPIP is dissolved in solution.
The end point of the titration is reached.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: DCPIP is normally blue but becomes colorless when it is reduced (gains electrons).

pageData.question: You are performing a titration of vitamin C, or ascorbic acid, using DCPIP. Colorless ascorbic acid solution is added to a flask and blue DCPIP solution is added to a syringe. As you add the DCPIP to the flask dropwise, you observe that the blue color of each drop disappears quickly and the solution in the flask remains colorless. Which of the following best describes the significance of the disappearing blue color during this titration?

options.text: All the DCPIP in each drop reacted with the ascorbic acid in the flask.
The equivalence point of the titration has been reached.
The DCPIP drops are being oxidized by the ascorbic acid in the flask.
The ascorbic acid solution is more concentrated than the DCPIP solution.
The DCPIP solution is more acidic than the ascorbic acid solution.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: DCPIP becomes colorless when it is reduced. If the DCPIP drops become colorless when added to the flask, it means there is something in the flask reacting with and reducing the DCPIP.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: DCPIP is a common indicator used in redox titrations because when it gains electrons, or is reduced, by an analyte like vitamin C, it changes color from blue to colorless. This color change makes it easy to distinguish at what point the analyte has been consumed by the redox reaction.

img.alt: Figure 2. Molecular equation with structures of DCPIP as it is oxidized.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: DCPIP is a common indicator used in redox titrations because when it gains electrons, or is reduced, by an analyte like vitamin C, it changes color from blue to colorless. This color change makes it easy to distinguish at what point the analyte has been consumed by the redox reaction.

img.alt: Figure 2. Molecular equation with structures of DCPIP as it is oxidized.

pageData.desc: A workflow diagram of the Determination of Vitamin C Concentration by Redox Titration investigation. To prepare for the investigation you will prepare the ascorbic acid stock solution, prepare the unknown ascorbic acid solution, and prepare the DCPIP solution. In Activity One you will determine the color of the titration end point, then titrate ascorbic acid samples of known concentration. In Activity Two you will titrate a sample of unknown ascorbic acid solution three times. You will then create a standard curve of Activity One data, then calculate the concentration of the unknown ascorbic acid solution. The final step is to clean up the investigation
pageData.altText: A workflow diagram of the Determination of Vitamin C Concentration by Redox Titration investigation. To prepare for the investigation you will prepare the ascorbic acid stock solution, prepare the unknown ascorbic acid solution, and prepare the DCPIP solution. In Activity One you will determine the color of the titration end point, then titrate ascorbic acid samples of known concentration. In Activity Two you will titrate a sample of unknown ascorbic acid solution three times. You will then create a standard curve of Activity One data, then calculate the concentration of the unknown ascorbic acid solution. The final step is to clean up the investigation

pageData.text: <span class=bodyParaLineBreak>Read all of the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections. <span class=bodyParaLineBreak>The powder 2,6-dichlorophenolindophenol (DCPIP) and its solutions will stain skin or clothing. Wear gloves when using this chemical, however there are no hazards associated with this chemical. <span class=bodyParaLineBreak>Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing this activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing this investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the goal of this investigation?

options.text: to prepare a standard curve using solutions of ascorbic acid of known concentration to compare to an unknown sample
to determine the concentration of an unknown DCPIP solution by finding the end point of a redox titration with ascorbic acid solution
to compare the end point of a redox titration with DCPIP as the titrant versus ascorbic acid as the titrant
to determine the balanced half-reactions of the reduction of DCPIP by ascorbic acid
to determine the change in ascorbic acid concentration of a solution over time using a series of redox titrations

assestmentData.question: Vitamin C oxidizes easily with the air. Which of the following precautions should you take during the investigation given this information?

options.text: The ascorbic acid stock solution should be prepared just before use.
The ascorbic acid stock solution should be kept chilled throughout the investigation.
The ascorbic acid stock solution should be diluted prior to use.
The ascorbic acid stock solution should be prepared in an opaque container.
The ascorbic acid stock solution should be prepared with the addition of a stabilizing agent.

assestmentData.question: This investigation involves calculating the molarity of ascorbic acid solutions. If a solution is prepared by dissolving 2.00 grams of ascorbic acid, C<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>H<sub class=bodySubscript>8</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>, in 1 liter of water, what is the molarity of the solution?
Which of the following best describes the components of the redox titrations to be performed in this investigation?

options.text: Ascorbic acid solution is the analyte; DCPIP solution is the titrant and indicator.
DCPIP solution is the analyte; ascorbic acid solution is the titrant and indicator.
Ascorbic acid solution is the analyte; DCPIP solution is the titrant; phenolphthalein is the indicator.
DCPIP solution is the analyte; ascorbic acid solution is the titrant; Bogen’s Universal Indicator is the indicator.
Ascorbic acid solution is the analyte; Vitamin C solution is the titrant; DCPIP is the indicator.

assestmentData.question: In this investigation, which of the following events will indicate the end point of the redox titration has been reached?

options.text: The addition of titrant to the analyte causes the solution in the flask to remain blue in color.
The addition of titrant to the analyte causes the solution in the flask to remain colorless.
The addition of titrant to the analyte causes the temperature of the solution in the flask to increase by five degrees Celsius.
The addition of titrant to the analyte causes the temperature of the solution in the flask to decrease by five degrees Celsius.
The addition of titrant to the analyte causes the pH of the solution in the flask to change from neutral to acidic.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the equivalence point of a titration?

options.text: The state at which all the analyte has reacted with all the titrant and no reagent exists in excess.
The state at which the concentration of the analyte used is equal to the concentration of the titrant used.
The state at which the volume of the analyte used is equal to the volume of the titrant used.
The state at which the reaction between the analyte and the titrant causes the solution to change from an acidic pH to a neutral pH.
The state at which the reaction between the analyte and the titrant causes the solution to change from a basic pH to a neutral pH.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the safety hazards associated with the powder 2,6-dichlorophenolindophenol (DCPIP) and its solutions?

options.text: This chemical will stain skin or clothing.
This chemical is a respiratory irritant.
This chemical is flammable.
This chemical is an environmental hazard.
This chemical is harmful if ingested.

assestmentData.question: This investigation uses a glass Erlenmeyer flask. Which of the following best describes the safe disposal of broken glass?

options.text: Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in a special receptacle on your school’s campus.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in a recycling bin.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the procedure.
Obtain all materials.
Fill the 250-mL beaker with pure water. Place a pipet with the water.

Write the following labels on the three 10-oz plastic cups:
  • ascorbic acid
  • waste
  • unknown
Just prior to beginning the lab, prepare the 2.00 g/L stock solution of ascorbic acid.

The ascorbic acid solution must be fresh for this experiment (remember, ascorbic acid is easily oxidized in air). Use the handle of the spoon as a small scoop to transfer the powder to the weigh boat.

1. Measure out 0.5 g ascorbic acid into a tared weigh boat.
  2. Transfer the ascorbic acid to the 10-oz plastic cup labeled "ascorbic acid."
  3. Add 250 mL of pure water to the plastic cup.
  4. Stir with the spoon until completely dissolved.
  5. Place a pipet with the ascorbic acid to be used with this solution.

Prepare the sample of unknown concentration.
  1. Fill the medicine cup between 50 and 100% full with the ascorbic acid solution.
  2. Transfer the ascorbic acid from the medicine cup to the 10-oz cup labeled "unknown."
  3. Add 50 mL pure water to the cup.
  4. Stir to mix.
Prepare the 2,6-dichlorophenolindophenol (DCPIP) by adding exactly 100 mL of pure water to the brown bottle. Use the 50-mL graduated cylinder to measure the water.
Cap the DCPIP bottle and shake to dissolve.
In Activity 1 you will perform a series of redox titrations using known dilutions of the ascorbic acid stock solution. This data will be plotted on a graph to create a standard curve in Activity 2.

pages.title: Developing a Standard Curve (9 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Developing a Standard Curve (9 steps)

pageData.text: Use the disposable pipet to add approximately 2 mL of distilled water to the 25-mL Erlenmeyer flask.
Place the flask on top of a sheet of white paper to make the color change more visible.
Add a single drop of DCPIP solution to this flask. The solution will turn blue. This is the color that indicates the end point.
Empty the flask into the 10-oz waste cup.
Rinse the flask with pure water from the 250-mL beaker using the disposable pipet and empty the rinse water into the waste cup.

Fill the syringe with the DCPIP solution.
  1. Fill the plastic medicine cup approximately half full with DCPIP solution.
  2. Fill the syringe with this DCPIP solution to the 5.0-mL mark.
  3. If there are any air bubbles in the syringe or in the tip, empty the solution back into the cup until the air bubbles are gone.
Place the syringe on a weigh boat or a piece of foil in between uses to avoid staining the work surface. Label all pipets to help keep track of pipets and to avoid cross contamination.

Perform the titration for the 0.5 g/L ascorbic acid sample:
  1. Transfer 0.5 mL of the ascorbic acid stock solution to the flask. Add 1.5 mL distilled water to insure that there is sufficient volume in the flask to swirl.
  2. Record the initial volume in the syringe as 5.0 mL on the data table for 0.5 g/L ascorbic acid.
  3. Transfer DCPIP to the flask drop-wise from the syringe until the solution in the flask has a distinct blue hue similar to what was seen in step 4.
  4. Gently swirl the flask as needed to achieve a uniform color.
The solution may take on a yellow tint, especially as the concentration of ascorbic acid increases. Only consider the end point reached if the solution is blue or a very persistent green.

1. Take a picture of the flask and record the final volume of the solution in the syringe to ±0.1 mL in Data Table 1 for 0.5 g/L ascorbic acid.
  2. Empty the flask into the 10-oz cup for waste.
  3. Rinse the flask with pure water from the beaker using the disposable pipet and empty the rinse water into the waste cup.

Perform the titration for the 1.0 g/L sample.
  1. Transfer 1.0 mL of the ascorbic acid stock solution to the flask.
  2. Add 1.0 mL pure water to the flask.
  3. Refill the syringe with DCPIP to the 5.0-mL mark.
  4. Perform the titration using the same steps as above.
  5. When finished, empty and rinse the flask with pure water.
  6. Record the final volume of the solution in the data table.

Some titrations will require refilling the syringe. Record the total volume from the first syringe before refilling the syringe. Keep track of the volume in each syringe used in the titration. Add all the volumes for the final volume to reach the end point.

Perform the titration for the 1.5 g/L ascorbic acid sample.
  1. Transfer 1.5 mL ascorbic acid stock solution to the flask.
  2. Add 0.5 mL pure water to the flask.
  3. Follow the same procedure as the other titration.

Perform the titration for the 2.0 g/L ascorbic acid sample.
  1. Transfer 2.0 mL of the ascorbic acid to the flask. Do not add any additional water.
  2. Follow the same procedures.

In Activity 2 you will perform another series of redox titrations using the ascorbic acid solution of unknown concentration. To determine the concentration of the unknown, you will create a graph of total DCPIP volume versus ascorbic acid concentration and plot the data from Activity 1. You will add a trendline to the graph; this is your standard curve. By determining the equation of the standard curve line, you can solve for the ascorbic acid concentration of the unknown in each trial and calculate an average value.

pages.title: Titrating the Unknown Concentration (11 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Titrating the Unknown Concentration (11 steps)

pageData.text: Transfer 2.0 mL of the unknown sample to the 25-mL Erlenmeyer flask.
Refill the syringe with DCPIP to the 5.0-mL mark.
Transfer DCPIP to the flask drop-wise from the syringe until the solution in the flask has a distinct blue-green hue similar to what was seen in the previous titrations.
Gently swirl the flask as needed to achieve a uniform color.
Refill the syringe as needed. Keep track of the number of syringes used for the titration.
Record the final volume of the solution in the syringe to ±0.0 mL on the data sheet for Unknown Trial 1.
Empty the flask into the 10-oz cup for waste. Rinse the flask with pure water and empty the rinse water into the waste cup.
Repeat the titration of the unknown concentration two more times.
Create a graph from containing the data from Activity 1. Ascorbic acid concentration will be the x-axis, and total volume of DCPIP will be the y-axis.
Add a trendline to the graph; set the y-intercept equal to zero. Record the equation of the line in Data Table 2.
Calculate the concentration of ascorbic acid in each unknown trial. The total volume is y, and solve for x for each trial to determine the concentration of ascorbic acid.

pageData.title: Disposal and Cleanup
text: Dispose of any unused chemicals down the drain with excess running water.
Wash and dry all lab equipment and return to equipment kit.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

text: List the likely sources of error in this experiment, and if those sources of error would most likely lead to the calculated concentration of vitamin C in the sample to be greater than or less than its actual value.
Based on the results of your titration, what volume of the sample would an adult need to consume to reach the recommended daily amount?

pageData.altText: Figure 1. A molecule of vitamin C
Figure 2. Molecular equation with structures of DCPIP as it is oxidized
Figure 3. Wedge and dash structure of ascorbic acid

A workflow diagram of the Determination of Vitamin C Concentration by Redox Titration investigation. To prepare for the investigation you will prepare the ascorbic acid stock solution, prepare the unknown ascorbic acid solution, and prepare the DCPIP solution. In Activity One you will determine the color of the titration end point, then titrate ascorbic acid samples of known concentration. In Activity Two you will titrate a sample of unknown ascorbic acid solution three times. You will then create a standard curve of Activity One data, then calculate the concentration of the unknown ascorbic acid solution. The final step is to clean up the investigation

pageData.content: Setting up and performing a titration

data.title: Antioxidant
data.content: A substance that removes potentially damaging oxidizing agents in a living organism.

data.title: Equivalence point
data.content: The state of a titration in which all the analyte has reacted with all the titrant and neither reagent exists in excess.

data.title: Oxidation
data.content: The loss of electrons during a reaction by a molecule, atom, or ion.

data.title: Reduction
data.content: The gaining of electrons during a reaction by a molecule, atom, or ion.
